titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Larry LaRocco Collection 1982-1994
titlestmt.sponsor: Funding for encoding this finding aid was provided, in part, by a grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities

publicationstmt.publisher: Boise State University Library, Special Collections and Archives

profiledesc.descrules: Finding aid based on DACS (Describing Archives: A Content Standard)

did.abstract: Chiefly documenting Larry LaRocco's two terms as one of Idaho's two members in the U.S. House of Representatives, 1991-1995.

bioghist.p: Larry LaRocco (1946- ) was twice elected to the U.S. House of Representatives from Idaho's 1st District, in 1990 and again in 1992.

scopecontent.p: The collection includes correspondence, press releases, newsletters, reports, studies, subject files, clippings, photos, tape and video recordings, and other papers, from LaRocco's service in Congress representing the First District of Idaho (North Idaho and the western side of the state); together with campaign and other political papers. Issues represented include wolf reintroduction, salmon recovery, wilderness, national forest and timber policies, forest health, Coeur d'Alene basin cleanup, Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area, and the Persian Gulf War (Operation Desert Storm).

Most of the material within each file is of a secondary nature; there is little correspondence. Although there is little personal correspondence within the general subject files from Washington, the regional offices retained letters and faxes in alphabetical constituent files. Communications between LaRocco and the other members of Congress relating to issues are found within the general files.

arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in fourteen series: 1. General files; 2.Campaigns; 3. Washington office; 4. Boise office; 5. Caldwell office; 6. Coeur d'Alene office; 7. Lewiston office; 8. Pre-Congressional; 9. Computer disks; 10. Tape cassettes; 11. Videotapes; 12. Maps; 13. Photos; and 14. Additions. The arrangement of materials within each series is by subject.

accessrestrict.p: Collection is available for research with the exception of select material. Contact Special Collections for additional information.

prefercite.p: Boise State University, Albertsons Library, Special Collections and Archives, Larry LaRocco Collection, MSS 139, [item description]

acqinfo.p: Gift of Mr. LaRocco, 1995, with subsequent additions.

processinfo.p: Printed matter which is not readily available in libraries was retained while government monographs and records of hearings were removed. Published items pertaining to Idaho were also removed so that they could be added to the library's Idaho book collection.

Larry LaRocco ran for the Idaho's 1st District seat in U.S. Congress four times. The first campaign in 1982 was against Larry Craig and was defeated. After successfully leading the drive for a state lottery in 1988, he ran again in 1990 against Skip Symser. LaRocco won with 53 percent of the vote. His announcement speech for this campaign is found in Box 1 of this series. Additional information concerning this election is in Series 4, Box 1.

In 1992, LaRocco sought reelection, running this time against Rachel Gilbert. The folders concerning this campaign are primarily press coverage, news releases, and campaign material on both candidates. Box 1, Folder 5 highlights LaRocco's positions concerning natural resources.

Helen Chenoweth was LaRocco's opponent in 1994. Again, natural resources dominate the debates especially the Endangered Species Act and Salmon. The files for this campaign contain a focus group study of voter issues and a position questionnaire along with general press coverage and news releases. LaRocco lost his bid for reelection by a close margin.

Voting; Sierra Club; Campaign, 1992; Conservation
Hall, Bill; Gilbert, Rachel
Listing of Bills Sponsored

The documents in Series 3 were created for in-house use by LaRocco's staff in Washington, DC, under the direction of Garry Wenske and Cherie Slayton. The papers contain material fundamental to operating a Congressional office. Box 1 comprises general files pertaining directly to LaRocco, for example biographies, personal records, and speeches. This box also contains information regarding services provided to constituents by their representatives and specific services available to members of Congress.

Appointments became a part of the office's activities following the 1992 election. Details of LaRocco's recommendations for Idaho's federal positions are found in Box 1. The nomination of John R. Tait for U.S. District Judge of Idaho became a point of political contention in the state and in Washington, DC Material relating to Tait has been collected in Box 12.

LaRocco's voting records are arranged by subject in Box 2 and include data received from special interest groups. Background to issues concerning Idaho is found Box 3. For example, transcripts from an oversight hearing provide insight to the controversy between the user and the conservator of western resources. Energy files directly relate to nuclear power and its waste storage.

Legislation sponsored and cosponsored by Larry LaRocco is found in Boxes 4 and 5. Box 4 has the cosponsored bills arranged by subject while in Box 5, they are arranged by Congressional session and number. These files also contain correspondence from members of Congress requesting support on their resolutions. Form letters (ROBO's) concerning various subjects are found in Box 6. These letters were for general distribution to LaRocco's Idaho constituents.

Specific correspondence is also found in Box 6. The files include correspondence from political colleagues, influential Idahoans, Idaho corporations, and the public. Letters classified by the staff as public relations are also in this box. General constituent requests are in Box 7.

Representatives in Congress are provided a budget for their mail services. A record a LaRocco's frankable mail is found in boxes 8, 9, and 10. In Box 11 are the schedules of Representative LaRocco's activities during his four years in Congress.

scopecontent.p: The Boise Office, administrated by Tom Kappenberger, served as the primary Idaho office plus a regional one. The original arrangement of the papers creates four subseries; issue files, news clippings, the 1994 Campaign, and the local office support.

There are two collections of the issue files; Boxes 1-5 are files from 1991-1993 and the files of 1994 are in Boxes 6 and 7. Major state issues identified by the staff make up the files in these seven boxes. For example, Idaho National Engineering Laboratory is not in Idaho's First District, but information can be found in this series relating to its operations and nuclear waste. The files include LaRocco's position, press releases, communications from constituents and correspondence between staff members pertaining and the issue.

The Boise papers show the political facets of LaRocco's Congressional office. Viewpoints on many state issues are often divided along political party lines. LaRocco, a Democrat, found himself in disputes with local Republicans over issues such as health care, grazing, and trade. The papers reveal the partisan aspects surrounding many of Idaho's interests.

Files applicable to the 1992 Campaign are found within the Issues Subseries (Box 1 and 6) while the office retained the material from the 1994 Campaign separately (Box 8). Boxes 9-11 (Clippings) are the newspaper articles arranged topically. The folder titles in this subseries correspond to the issue files.

The general operation files for the Boise Office are found in Box 12 and 13. "Legislative letters" are generic responses sent out by the regional offices to constituents. LaRocco's position on diary prices, China as a Most Favored Nation, or the Bryan Canyon (Idaho) Road Project are explained in these letters. 1991 and 1992 press releases issued by LaRocco are arranged chronologically in Box 12 and 13. Constituent communication is gathered under the heading of Public Relations. Outgoing letters of congratulation and condolences, responses to invitations and inquiries from Representative LaRocco to his constituents are filed chronologically. The Office also saved original letters and faxes from the public.

scopecontent.p: The Caldwell Office oversaw the Southwest corner of Idaho, covering Canyon, Owyhee, Payette, and Washington counties. The administrative papers for the office are interfiled with the subject files in an alphabetical arrangement.

The papers suggest that LaRocco's had a political base with the area's Hispanic community. To serve their interests, LaRocco was a member of Congressional Hispanic Caucus that strived for the passage of beneficial educational, employment, and health care legislation. The various proposals are described in many of this series' folders.

The regional offices' chief responsibility was to identify local concern and relay information to Boise and Washington, DC Questions about agriculture dominated the Caldwell Office. Water rights during the 1992 drought impelled LaRocco joined with the rest of Idaho's Congressional delegation to request federal funds for drought relief.

Much of the office's work was in response to individual problems. Notes were kept regarding constituent phone calls and summations of the call were sent to the Boise Office. Copies of the communications can be found in the files either under the subject of the call or in the general "Correspondence," Box 1, Folder 18.

Environmental issues are the primary focus of papers from the Coeur d'Alene Office. Mining and timber industry dominated the economy and the landscape of the region.

The effects of silver mining in the Panhandle region of Idaho created the Bunkerhill Superfund in 1992 providing federal money through the Environmental Protection Agency. At the urging of northern constituents, including the Coeur d'Alene Indian Tribe, LaRocco introduced legislation for the "cleanup of mining waste and restoration of natural resources in the watershed area of the Coeur d'Alene River, Coeur d'Alene Lake and the Spokane River." In his statement before on the House Floor, LaRocco described how 45% of nation's silver mined in the last 100 years has left the Silver Valley 72 million tons of tailings that have leached and spread into the Basin's rivers and lands. The State of Idaho, the Tribe, and the local citizenry devised a plan, contingent on federal funds, to restore the Basin. Additional materials on the topic can be found in Series 1, Boxes 9 and 10.

The timber industry has had an influential role in the policy of the forest management in the panhandle region. At odds with this strong economic base were the environmentalists who wished to restrict logging in the region. Background material from both sides of the issue was collected by the Coeur d'Alene Office to assist LaRocco in achieving a viable compromise. A survey in Box 4, Folder 24, analyzed Idahoans' knowledge and attitudes about property rights, timber supply, trade and exports with regard with the logging industry. LaRocco held special town meetings in 1992 enabling his constituents to express their concerns directly to him. As a result, LaRocco introduced the Sustainable Forest and Communities Act of 1994.

With the decline of the timber and mining industry, the Panhandle region looked for alternative sources of income. The Taft Tunnel was one such project. A former series of train tunnels linking St. Regis, Montana to Avery, Idaho had become a popular trail for hikers, mountain bikers and horseback riders. Concerns for their safety within the tunnels initiated federal funding being appropriated in 1994.
Several issues concerning Idaho's northern countries have files in this series. Files concerning human rights and white supremacists are found in Box 2, Folders 1 and 45.
Though there are a few office operation files interspersed with the subjects. The general office files including constituent communication are in Box 5, Folders 13-31.

Lewiston, Idaho is located between the Snake and Clearwater River adjacent to several national forests. The city's economic reliance on natural resources is evident in the files collected by LaRocco's regional staff. Though such issues as health care and clean water are discussed in the papers, dominate throughout the series are materials about the environment.

The efforts to save the salmon from extinction are well documented here. Drawdowns on the Lower Granite and Dworshak drew negative reactions from area residents. Petitions against the action can be found in Box 1, Folder 15. Files 19-26 in Box 2 pertain directly to the salmon. They contain publications from public and private organizations evaluating the situation, and, communications from public officials and private citizens. Public opinions pertaining to the environment are found throughout the files.

Debates concerning the addition of wilderness areas to Idaho are found in the boxes. Lewiston is a timber town and directly affected by logging restrictions and changes in governmental policies. Documentation of timber, mining and recreational concerns are in the Idaho Wilderness files.
Box 3 contains the general files for the office. Included in these is information and feedback from the town meetings on health care.

Prior to his election to the House of Representatives in 1990, Larry LaRocco had ran for the position in 1982 against Larry Craig. He also challenged Boisean Jim Risch for a state legislative seat in 1986. LaRocco was defeated in both races. Series 8, Box 1, Folders 1 holds campaign material for these elections. Folder 2 contains copies of speeches from the 1984 campaign primarily from the National Democratic Convention.

The election year of 1988 brought gaming to the forefront of Idaho politics. LaRocco headed the committee for the passage of a referendum f establishing a State Lottery. The papers from Idahoans or the Lottery are retained in Box 1, Folders 4-14.

scopecontent.p: These 3 1/4 inch computer disks contain office reports and records and served as working tools for the staff. The program for the majority of files on the disks is to Word Perfect 5.1. An inventory of the files found that not all were accessible, passwords maybe required or the proper technical support is not available in the department. Of the readable material, it is apparent that many of the texts are found in hard copy within the individual office files.

The Washington Office disks contain the letters sent to constituents in an alphabetical arrangement on eleven disks. There are approximately 220 files per disk. Many of the letters were composed by members of LaRocco's staff.

A disk from the Washington Office contains transcripts of the hearings on the Sustainable Forest and Communities Act, held in Boise and Lewiston in August, 1993. A disk labeled "Campaign 1994" is includes press releases and speeches as part of its 96 files.

The Boise office computer disks are labeled "Backup" and appear to be a backup of the local office's hard drive. It is difficult to discern what was originally LaRocco correspondence and what was Tom Knappenberger and Myrna Stasser. An outline of the eleven disks is listed below:
2 Has corrupt files, unable to read
3 Wilderness robo letters, general letters to constituents
4 Letters to the press regarding specific issues. Also contains, Commencement Address to St. Maries High School, 1994
5 Has corrupt files, unable to read
Position notes on Fair Credit Reporting Act and Child Support Enforcement
9 Summary of media treatment of Campaign, 1994
10 Robo letters to constituents pertaining to specific subjects
Kristi Bell, Administrative Assistant for the Coeur d'Alene Office kept constituent correspondence and robo letters on the one disk that was included in the regional offices files.
The disk transferred from the Lewiston Office contains letters to constituents concerning wilderness issues and general working files.

The audiovisual materials pertain directly to congressional activities of Larry LaRocco. Eight cassettes and more than forty videos (see Series 11) typify the various uses of media in political campaigns. Debates between LaRocco and his opponents, speeches, television interviews, and news out takes for the 1992 and 1994 campaigns are included in the collection. Political ads including initial graphics and interviews have been retained.

LaRocco conducted town meetings held throughout Idaho's 1st Congressional District. Several meetings focused on the issues of wilderness and land use in Idahos National Forests. The testimony from these meetings contributed to LaRocco's proposed wilderness legislation. These meetings were frequently recorded by his staff members. Hearings concerning the role of telecommunication in health care reform are in the series.

Appearances in Congress and on television can be seen in the video collection. LaRocco expresses his opinion on the Persian Gulf War, Idaho Wilderness, Desert Preservation, and timber sales on these tapes.

The maps in Series 12 focus on the environmental issues confronting Idaho's elected officials during LaRocco's two terms as Representative. The first seven sets show negotiated areas in Idaho's debate over wilderness. Set I illustrate earlier designated areas before 1991. Sets II-VI show the areas involved in LaRocco's Wilderness proposals. H.R. 1570 was first introduced in March of 1993.

After much debate and compromise, LaRocco reintroduced The Idaho Wilderness, Sustainable Forests and Communities Act in January of 1994, H.R. 3732. The bill was written in response to the Wilderness Equity Act of 1994 in an attempt to create a "balanced approach" to Idaho's natural resources.

Maps of the Arkansas-Idaho Land Exchanged of 1992 are found in this Series. H.R. 5336 authorized the exchange of public lands in Idaho for equal valued hardwood bottom land. Idaho forest lands were traded to Potlatch, Inc. for timber harvests while the company's Arkansas land was added to the United States protected wetlands. Series 1, Box 3, Folders 1-5 contains testimony and documents chronicling the exchange.

In 1991, Larry LaRocco initiated a bill that would designate certain public lands in Idaho as the Snake River Bird of Prey National Conservation Area. Map Set X of the series indicates the final preservation area. Files supporting the passage of the legislation are found in Series 1, Box 3 and 4.

The photographs contained in the Larry LaRocco Collection consist of over 200 photographs and negatives. Many are candid snapshots taken during personal appearances. A large portion of photographs directly relate to his three campaigns for Congress. LaRocco was frequently photographed with constituents in visited Washington, DC and on his visits home to Idaho. Samples of these photos are in the collection.

Several dignitaries were photographed with the Representative, such as Senator Albert Gore, Jr., Governor Cecil Andrus and Speaker of the House, Tom Foley. Formal portraits of LaRocco in color and black and white can be found the files. Representative LaRocco and Senator Gephart were photographed touring Boise computer company, Micron, Inc.

Photographs relating to legislation have been included in the series. Visits to the Birds of Prey Natural Conservation Area, the North Fork of the Payette River, and a Pro-Choice Rally at the State Capitol show LaRocco's interest in controversial Idaho issues. Representative LaRocco proposed to honor the participants in the Persian Gulf War, a medal, photographs of which can be found in the collection. The actual medal can be seen in the collection's memorabilia. Photographs of Automatic Weapons restricted by the "Brady Bill", defense photos of the Stealth Bomber and the Super Conducting Super Collider are included in the collection.
